title-group.article-title: Strength Assessment and Bonding Study of Aluminum Short Fiber-Reinforced Gypsum Composites

abstract.p: In this study, tensile strength of gypsum-based composite with aluminum fibers up to 15 vol.% was studied. To increase the interfacial bond strength between fibers and matrix, aluminum fibers were anodized under different conditions. Single fiber pull-out tests were carried out to investigate the bond strength. The interface was examined by scanning electron microscope. The ability of the composites to withstand longitudinal tensile load was also studied by tensile tests of dog bone-shaped, randomly oriented fiber-reinforced gypsum. By the introduction of aluminum fibers in gypsum as a randomly oriented composite, considerable increment in the strength is achieved and the toughness of the composite improves significantly. Although, anodizing provides a considerable effect on pull out force via development of stronger interface with gypsum, it does not significantly affect the overall strength of the composite. A mathematical model has been developed to predict the strength of the composites with up to 15 vol.% aluminum fibers. The obtained results are in good agreement with the experimental data.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Damage evaluations of the ceramic matrix composites are interesting subjects, which should be carried out continuously to present the properties of these materials better. The literature survey shows that there are numerous works on damage evaluations of cement-based materials (Al-Rub and Voyiadjis, 2009; Basista and Weglewski, 2009; Nam et al., 2009; Voyiadjis et al., 2009; Chandrasekaran et al., 2010; Di Luzio et al., 2010; Kumar and Barai, 2010; Li and Li, 2010; Sageresan et al., 2010); however, investigations on the other building materials have remained insufficient. Gypsum material with excellent properties such as lightness, low expense, and good appearance has emerged as a unique construction material, although its brittleness and permeability have limited its extensive applications. Several works have been carried out to improve the physical and mechanical properties of gypsum; Wu and Dare (2004) described axial and shear behavior of glass fiber-reinforced gypsum (GFRG) wall panels. Cyclic shear tests were conducted by Wu (2004) to study the effect of reinforcement continuity on the performance of shear-dominated GFRG walls. Although, no significant effect on the shear strength of GFRG walls was observed, the shear strength at load reversal increases for wall panels with continuous longitudinal reinforcement. Surendra and Baehr (1977) fabricated sheets by spraying gypsum slurry with chopped glass fibers to improve its tensile strength and ductility. The influence of volume fraction and length of fibers together was studied; density and type of matrix on flexural properties and impact strength were also studied. Mechanical properties of cork–gypsum composites and their acoustic absorption coefficient and thermal conductivity have been experimentally obtained by Hernández-Olivares et al. (1999). Although the mechanical properties of the produced composites were poor, good interaction between gypsum matrix and cork granules was observed. A study on the microstructure and mechanical behavior of plaster composites containing different concentrations of polyamide fibers has been reported by Eve et al. (2002). Reduction in Young’s modulus, flexural strength, and compressive strength was reported by fiber concentration increment seemingly, due to the weak fiber/matrix interface. A notable improvement on the mechanical properties of cotton stalk/gypsum composite was obtained in a recent study by Li et al. (2003) through treatment of cotton stalk fiber surface with styrene acrylic emulsion. The interfacial combined state of cotton stalk fiber/gypsum was also improved effectively by this treatment. All these results indicate the importance of bond strength between fibers and gypsum on the strengthening effect of fibers.

A desirable composite with appropriate mechanical properties would be obtained if the stress transfer between matrix and fibers is well accomplished, since the bond strength established between the constituents along the interface determines the load transfer ability and characteristics of the interaction between propagating cracks and fibers Sih and Chen (1973). The higher the bonding strength, the greater the tensile strength of the fibers must be in order to withstand transferred load through interface.

The purpose of this study is to utilize the strengthening effect of short aluminum fibers in gypsum, similar to those observed in concrete through the introduction of steel fibers. In this way, it may be possible to improve mechanical properties of gypsum by the presence of a low-density, fire-, and corrosion-resistance aluminum fibers. Compared to the low fire resistance of polymeric fibers and toxicity of some others such as asbestos, if economically feasible, aluminum fiber maybe an appropriate candidate for this purpose.

In this study, random distribution of aluminum short fibers in gypsum base composite was studied. To increase the stress transfer-ability, aluminum fibers were anodized under different conditions. In this way, thin anodic porous oxide of uniform thickness is produced on the surface of aluminum fibers. The characteristic of the anodic layer is strongly affected by fabrication variables (Asoh et al., 2001; Alwitt, 2002). The ideal framework of this layer has a cellular structure with a central pore in each cell (Asoh et al., 2001). The conditions for obtaining ideally ordered anodic porous alumina with uniform cell size of regular hexagons were also studied by Masuda et al. (1997, 2000).

Also, in this study, a mathematical model has been developed to evaluate tensile strength of the produced composites. This model is based on the earlier theories for load transfer through interface presented by Cox (1952) and Nayfeh (1977) combined with the purely empirical failure criterion. The obtained results confirm that the modified shear lag model can be an effective tool for stress evaluation of fiber-reinforced composites.

sec.title: THEORY
sec.p: According to the law of mixtures, tensile strength of the aligned fiber reinforced composites, σc, is given as follows: (1) where σ¯f is the average fiber axial stress, σm the strength of the matrix, and f the volume fraction of fibers. Considering the modified relation originally proposed by Cox (1952), the average fiber axial stress along the interface is given by: (2) where Ef is the fiber’s modulus of elasticity, e the matrix strain, β the shear-lag parameter, and l the length of the fiber. Rosen (1965), Lauke and Shultrich (1983), and Fu et al. (1994) proposed different methods to reduce the approximations and assumptions of the shear lag model. Since the Cox’s analysis with its shear lag parameter does not always give satisfactory results especially in the concentric cylinder model calculations (Nairn, 1997; Liu and Nairn, 1999), the Cox’s shear lag parameter could be replaced with another ascertained representation following Nayfeh (1977) (using Zhandarov et al. (2000) notation); (3) where Em is the modulus of elasticity of matrix, Gf and Gm the shear moduli of fiber and matrix, respectively, and rf the fiber’s radius. Half the center-to-center separation of the fibers is not necessary to measure in this form of the shear lag parameter, while Fu et al. (2000) have shown that the effect of inter-fiber separation on the stress transfer from matrix to fiber in the multi-short fiber composites is relatively small.

If the direction of the fibers is different from that of the applied load, some modification should be considered, since the tensile strength of the off-axis unidirectional short fiber composites significantly depends on the off-axis angle, θ.

To analyze the laminated composites, the maximum stress criterion together with an interactive failure criterion may be used for anisotropic materials expressed by an inequality known as Tsai–Hill criterion. These two failure criteria that were originally proposed for laminated composites could also be assumed to be applicable for random fiber-reinforced composites, since the inter-fiber separation (or fiber end gap) is not considered in the original model. To take into account, the interaction of stress components, Tsai–Hill equation is considered. The longitudinal stress in a composite with parallel fibers in the normal direction equals the tensile strength, σc. It may also be assumed that the transverse strength of the aligned short fiber-reinforced composite is equal to the matrix strength.

Substituting the critical stress values from the maximum stress criterion in two-dimensional (2D) state of stress in Tsai–Hill criterion, the ultimate tensile strength of a composite with parallel fibers oriented at an angle of θ is given as follows: (4) where σ1′ and σ2′ are the longitudinal and transverse stresses of composite with parallel fibers in the normal and perpendicular directions equal to σc and σm, respectively, and τ the shear stress component. As Tresca criterion predicts, the shear stress component is equal to the half value of matrix tensile stress (0.5σm). Integrating this equation with respect to θ would lead to the tensile stress of a composite with randomly oriented fibers. Since the stress given in Equation (4), σ1′, is a function of fiber length (or fiber aspect ratio) and also fiber volume fraction, this equation may be integrated with respect to θ and numerically calculated as a function of fiber length (or fiber aspect ratio) and fiber volume fraction to determine the tensile strength of the composites, as it will be shown later.

sec.title: MATERIALS AND EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURE
sec.p:
In this study, commercial gypsum was used to produce the studied composites. To ensure the consistency of the gypsum characteristics, gypsum powder and water were mixed at a constant ratio of 1 : 1. Afterward, those were cast in the standard bone-shaped molds similar to those used for tensile studies of the cementitious materials (Figure 1). The semi-set gypsum samples were extracted from the molds after 5 min and left in a dry atmosphere at 35°C for 7 days. To obtain the tensile strength, 12-set gypsum specimens were tested by an Instron tensile machine under the cross-head displacement control with the rate of 2 mm/min. All tensile tests were conducted in an environment of 25°C with 30% humidity and the samples were placed in the lower grip vertically. The mean tensile strength was obtained to be 0.48 MPa with standard deviation (SD) of 0.03. Figure 1.
Schematic illustration of bone-shaped tensile test specimen.

High-accuracy acoustic-ultrasonic measurements for the stress wave factor and ultrasonic velocity were performed using an AET 206 AU (Acoustic Emission Technology Corporation, USA) using 26-mm cube gypsum specimens. The velocity of longitudinal and transverse ultrasonic waves was measured and used to calculate Young’s modulus and Poisson’s ratio (Zawrah and El-Gazery, 2007). Twelve tests were performed on gypsum specimens and the mean values along with the SD were determined, which are illustrated in Table 1. Table 1.

Drawn aluminum wires with 1 mm diameter were used for making fibers. To measure the tensile strength of the fibers, 10 tensile tests were conducted on the as-received aluminum fibers. The mean value of the obtained tensile strength along with the Young’s modulus of aluminum fibers and the value of Poisson’s ratio which was cited from Callister (2005) are shown in Table 2. Table 2.

To anodize the aluminum fibers, as-received wires were immersed in an anodizing bath of 10% dilute sulfuric acid. Electrical current was established by means of continuous direct current power supply and copper sheets were used as cathodes. Anodizing process was carried out under three different conditions, namely Type I, II, and III, depending on various parameters such as applied voltage and time, as illustrated in Table 3. Table 3.

To conduct the pull-out test, a cubic gypsum sample with 50 mm height containing an aluminum fiber placed in the middle of the upper face of the cube was cast in a cube mold. To hold the fiber in the right position, a perforated polymeric strip was used (Figure 2). The total length of the fiber was 50 mm, of which 15 mm was embedded in the gypsum. After setting, samples were taken off from the molds and placed in a 35°C dry atmosphere for 7 days; fibers were pulled out of the gypsum by an Instron tensile machine with a tensile rate of 5 mm/min using special fixtures. Pull-out tests were conducted on plain aluminum, Type I, II, and III anodized fibers. For each condition, 10 tests were performed and the mean value was determined. Figure 2.
Schematic illustration of pull-out test specimen.

To study the effect of plain aluminum and anodized aluminum fibers on tensile strength, bone-shaped gypsum composites containing various amounts of fibers up to 15 vol.% were made. The length and diameter of the fibers were 12 and 1 mm, respectively, and those were embedded into the gypsum matrix in a random manner. Twelve tensile tests were carried out on each type of the composite specimens and the mean value was determined.

sec.title: Bonding Study
sec.p:
Figure 3 illustrates the results of pull-out tests for plain aluminum and anodized aluminum fibers embedded into the gypsum sample. The pull-out load was measured by tensile machine at every 0.2-mm displacement interval for each specimen and the mean values were traced using regression analysis. As it is seen, by anodizing, the pull-out load (i.e., the strength of interfacial bonding) has increased remarkably. The higher the anodizing voltage and time, the greater the bonding strength (Figure 3). However, regarding the area under the load–displacement curves, maximum pull-out energy is observed in Type II anodized fiber. Figure 3.
Load–displacement curves of pull-out test for plain aluminum, Type I, II, and III anodized fibers.

The ideal framework of alumina established on the surface of aluminum fibers during anodizing process is shown in Figure 4 (Asoh et al., 2001). Masuda et al. (2001) and Asoh et al. (2003) have shown that this cellular structure is not always hexagonal and not often by this exact order. However, the presence of central pore in each cell may facilitate favorable adhesion with gypsum crystals at microscopic scale. The results obtained by scanning electron microscopic (SEM) studies of the fiber’s surface after pull out are shown in Figures 5–7. It is noted that depending on the type of anodizing, different densities of gypsum crystals were impregnated on the fiber’s surface. Type III anodization was carried out under higher voltage and longer time in comparison to the Type I and II. Thus, roughness of the anodic alumina layer formed on the surface of Al fiber has increased due to more interfacial contact between fiber’s surface and gypsum crystals, hence attracting larger amount of gypsum seeds into the crevices of the anodized surface (Figures 5–7). Figure 4.
Ideal framework of anodic porous alumina at the surface of aluminum (Asoh et al., 2001). Figure 5.
SEM image from the surface of Type I anodized aluminum fiber in the fracture surface of the tensile specimen. Figure 6.
SEM image from the surface of Type II anodized aluminum fiber in the fracture surface of the tensile specimen. Figure 7.
SEM image from the surface of Type III anodized aluminum fiber in the fracture surface of the tensile specimen.

Formation of cracks on the anodized layer can be seen from the SEM images (Figures 5–7). The length and depth of the cracks increase through intensification of the anodizing conditions (i.e., higher anodizing voltage and longer time). It is unlikely that these cracks are produced via pore enlargements, since Ono and Masuko (2003) have indicated that when the voltage is reduced to values lower than 10 V during anodizing process, the porosity in the film (i.e., the size of pores) formed on the surface of the aluminum substrate increases remarkably. However, by conducting the anodizing process under higher voltage (>6 V) and longer time (>120 min), the anodized layer tends to behave in a more brittle manner, as it is illustrated in Figure 3. Given the ceramic nature of anodized layer, the stress induced due to raising temperature from −15°C (i.e., anodizing bath temperature) to ambient temperature, in the wake of the difference between the volume expansion coefficients of the constituents, may cause crack formation. Vrublevsky et al. (2003) have shown that the volume expansion factor (i.e., ratio of the volume of anodic aluminum oxide to the volume of consumed aluminum) is proportional to the anodizing voltage. Thus, the volume expansion factor is increased by applying higher voltage in anodizing process, consequently developing larger microcracks on the surface of fibers.

sec.title: Strength Evaluation
sec.p:
Tensile strength of plain aluminum, Type I, II, and III anodized fiber-reinforced gypsum composites for five different fiber volume fractions is presented in Table 4. Ultimate tensile strength of gypsum composites containing up to 15 vol.% of randomly oriented anodized fibers and plain aluminum fibers is illustrated in Figure 8. Since the difference between the strength of gypsum composites containing Type I, II, and III anodized fibers is negligible (Table 4), a mean value for the tensile strength of composites containing anodized fibers is considered for each fiber volume fraction. In other words, type of anodizing has no significant effect on the tensile strength of aluminum/gypsum composites. Figure 8.

The mean strength of the composites with anodized fibers is slightly higher than the composites containing plain aluminum fibers, where the difference diminishes as the volume fraction of fibers is increased. It may be concluded that the bond strength between aluminum fibers and gypsum matrix loses its effect on tensile strength by increasing the volume fraction of fibers in the composites.

The higher the volume fraction of fibers, the lower the SD of the results as it is seen in Table 4, since at high volume fraction of fibers, more ideal random orientation of the fibers may be achieved.

By increasing the volume fraction of fibers, tensile strength of composite increases. Nevertheless, there is a limit for the strengthening effect of the fibers, where by increasing the fiber concentration, the rate of strength increment reduces. These results are consistent with the previous results obtained for other ceramic matrix composites (Eve et al., 2002). This effect is called overfiberization and will be further discussed. Despite remarkable effect of anodizing on the pull-out load, its effect on strengthening of randomly oriented 12-mm short fibers in gypsum matrix is not significant; given the inhomogeneous and porous morphology of the gypsum matrix, the bond strengthening caused by anodizing does not seem to have considerable effect on preventing matrix cracking. Thus, it is justified to conclude that by anodizing the aluminum fibers, improvement on the tensile strength is not remarkable. Similar results have been obtained for cork–gypsum composites by Hernández-Olivares et al. (1999), where by increasing bond strength between cork fiber and the gypsum matrix, no significant improvement in the strength of the composites was observed.

Typical stress–displacement curves of the gypsum composite containing 8% volume fraction of aluminum and anodized aluminum fibers obtained from tensile tests are shown in Figure 9. Strengthening effect of anodizing aluminum fibers is not considerable unlike as it maybe anticipated considering its effect on pull-out load. Nevertheless, the effect of anodizing on the toughness of composites (proportional to the area under load–displacement curves in Figure 9) is significant. Generally, the strengthening mechanism in the composite reinforced with fibers includes load transfer from matrix to fibers, resulting in the reduction of imposed stress on the matrix, therefore impeding crack nucleation. Among the toughening mechanism proposed for ceramic matrix composites, the most probable mechanisms that may occur in the ceramic matrix gypsum composites include bridging, pull out, and deflection (Figure 10). Since the fracture surface of the produced composites is relatively flat (Figure 11), the occurrence of deflection mechanism is improbable. Therefore, the most probable mechanism controlling the toughness of composites seems to be pull out, considering much higher strength of aluminum fibers compared to the brittle gypsum, failure of fibers is not expected during tensile loading. This was justified by fractographic studies where no broken fiber was observed on the fracture surface. Figure 9.
Stress–displacement of plain gypsum along with gypsum composites containing 8% volume fraction of plain Al and Type III anodized fibers. Figure 10.
The proposed toughening mechanisms in short fiber-reinforced composites, (a) bridging, (b) pull out, and (c) deflection. Figure 11.
Fracture surface of plain aluminum fiber reinforced gypsum composite.

The effect of anodizing on fracture toughness of composites is significant, since after initial fracture caused by cracking of the brittle matrix, the dominant toughening mechanism is pull out, where the resistance of fibers against pull out plays a crucial role in consumption energy of tensile loading, similar to those observed in the ceramic matrix composites (Becher et al., 1988; Becher, 1990).

To determine the strength of randomly oriented fiber-reinforced composites, Equation (4) was integrated with respect to θ and numerically calculated as a function of volume fraction of fibers; (5) where σRandom is the tensile strength of the composite and φ a function depending on the distribution of fiber’s orientation. Figure 12 illustrates two possible orientation distributions of fibers, one where the distribution is random and all orientations are equally preferred, and one where there is a tendency to a single orientation or some degree of alignment. The total amount of fiber must be the volume fraction of fibers. Thus, if it is assumed that the distribution of fibers is uniform, then f \ π could be replaced by ф (θ). This orientation distribution of fibers is used in our theoretical model. Figure 12.
Two possible orientation distributions of fibers in the matrix, (a) random distribution, and (b) a tendency to a single orientation or some degree of alignment.

The prediction of the model for the tensile strength is in agreement with the experimental results (Figure 8). But, slight deviations from the experimental results are observed in high volume fraction of fibers. Although damage is a complex phenomenon in short fiber composites, one would expect that excessive matrix cracking, especially propagating cracks at the ends of the fibers, may be the major source of this behavior at the higher fiber concentration, just as indicated by Nguyen et al. (2005). It should be noted that when the fiber content in the matrix increases, fibers will eventually touch and form a continuous path of connected fibers that may be called the percolation point, following recent works on heterogeneous materials (Torquato, 2002). A lesser studied phenomenon is the rigidity percolation point in particulate or fiber composites. At this fiber volume fraction, it seems that there is just adequate matrix present in the composite to yield a rigid structure. At a volume fraction less than the rigidity percolation point, the fibers may form a continuous network, but this network has not enough rigidity and hence not adequate mechanical strength. In accordance with overfiberization of these composites, the occurrence of the percolation phenomenon is probable. These results are in accordance to the estimates for percolation threshold presented in 3D for isotropic fibers (Jeulin and Moreaud, 2006). Similar behavior has been observed in other ceramic matrix composites (Faber and Evans, 1983b), where by increasing the volume fraction of Al2O3 fibers in a SiCw matrix, the fracture toughness of the composites reached a maximum value, and then by further increment of volume fraction it decreased to zero. The same phenomenon was observed in lithium–alumino-silicate glass ceramic matrix composites at 20% volume fraction of Li2Si2O5 lath-shaped crystals (Faber and Evans, 1983a; Facca et al., 2007).

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: The results of this study show that the mechanical properties of gypsum improve by the presence of aluminum fibers. As it has been shown in this study, by the introduction of aluminum fibers in gypsum as a randomly oriented composite, considerable increment in the strength may be achieved and the toughness of the composite improves significantly. By anodizing aluminum fibers, a remarkable increase in the pull-out force is observed due to the better adhesion of anodized layer with gypsum crystals. The Type III anodized aluminum fibers has better adhesion with respect to Type I and II. However, Type II anodized aluminum fiber demonstrates the highest pull-out energy. In addition, the effect of anodizing on increasing the pull-out load is more remarkable than its effect on tensile strength of randomly oriented short fiber-reinforced gypsum composites. It may be concluded that the effect of anodizing is much more pronounced on the toughness of the gypsum composites than on tensile strength.

A mathematical model has also been presented to assess the tensile strength of gypsum reinforced with random short fibers. Despite the deviations at low and high fiber volume fractions, the experimental results are in good agreement with predictions of the model.
